title: 1 Lecture I: Course Introduction to al-Waraqat and the Science of Usul al-Fiqh [11/8/2025, Jumada al-Awwal 17, 1447 AH]
text:
Intention in Seeking Knowledge




“Whoever strives for knowledge for the Hereafter obtains great gain in righteousness.
But he is in utter loss who seeks knowledge to obtain advantage over people!”
— Poem attributed to Imam Abu Hanifa (رحمه الله)

Imam al-Haddad’s intention reads:
> “I intend to study and teach, to take and give a reminder, to take and give benefit, to take and give advantage, to encourage the holding fast to the Book of Allah and the way of His Messenger صلى الله عليه وسلم, to call to guidance and directing towards good, hoping for the countenance of Allah and His pleasure, His proximity and reward.”
Imam al-Dhahabi notes that a sincere seeker of knowledge will show humility, fear of Allah, and lack of pride; whereas one whose intention is worldly will grow arrogant, quarrel, and seek admiration.


This section introduces the purpose of al-Waraqat, outlines how Imam al-Haramain al-Juwayni defines fiqh and usul al-fiqh, and provides essential background on how Islamic legal texts are structured from short foundational texts (mutun) to layered commentaries.

Fun Fact — Titles of Scholars within the Shafi’i Madhhab



Within the Shafi’i school, scholars are often referenced by honorific titles rather than their names.
These titles indicate scholarly authority, rank, or specific contributions to the development of the madhhab.

Al-Qadi (القاضي)
Commonly used to refer to Qadi Abu Bakr al-Baqillani, the great Ash’ari Mutakallim and Usuli, though occasionally applied to other jurists who served as chief judges or early authorities in kalam and usul (like Qadi Abu Shuja’).
Al-Imam (الإمام)
Designates Imam al-Haramain al-Juwayni, the teacher of al-Ghazali and a pivotal systematizer of Shafi’i usul.
Al-Shaykhan (الشيخان)
Always refers to Imam al-Rafi’i and Imam al-Nawawi, whose opinions together form the later mu’tamad (established) position of the madhhab.
Ashab al-Wujuh (أصحاب الوجوه)
A select group of early mujtahid Imams within the madhhab who formulated independent opinions (wujuh), later codified by scholars like al-Nawawi and al-Rafi’i.
Some of these include Imam Muzani, Hujjat al-Islam Abu Hamid al-Ghazali, Imam Buwayti, and Abu Ishaq al-Shirazi.
Al-Mujaddid (المجدد)
Refers to revivers of the school’s teaching and methodology in their respective centuries—e.g., al-Shafi’i in the 2nd century, al-Nawawi in the 7th century, al-Suyuti in the 10th.
Shaykh al-Islam (شيخ الإسلام)
Refers almost always to Zakariyyah al-Ansari, the Mujaddid of the 9th century, as well as the teacher of many luminaries including Ibn Hajar al-Haytami, al-Khatib al-Shirbini, and Shams al-Din al-Ramli.








Usul al-Fiqh (أصول الفقه) means the foundational principles by which legal rulings are derived.
Let’s dive deeper into what this means exactly. However, before doing so, it’s important to understand how Islamic scholarship and texts are structured.




Before studying al-Waraqat, it’s very important to know that knowledge (as we’ll define later) in fiqh and usul al-fiqh is preserved through layered writings:







Type
Description




Matn (متن)
A short, foundational text that is concise and is often memorized. Example: al-Waraqat, Matn Abi Shuja, Safwat al-Zubad, etc.


Sharh (شرح)
A commentary that explains the matn. May be word-by-word or explanatory.


Hashiyah / Hawashi (حاشية / حواشي)
Marginal notes written on top of commentaries, also known as super-commentaries or glosses. Developed widely after the 8th century when writing another commentary was no longer beneficial due to existing works.


Taqrirat (تقريرات)
Clarifying notes a scholar writes on top of a hashiyah or commentary to correct, refine, or add legal detail.


Ta’liqat (تعليقات)
Short notes or remarks, often written by students or teachers. These may explain a point or clarify a difficult phrase and may also be a collection of recordings compiled into a book.












Two Types of Sharh (Commentaries)











Type
Arabic
Description




Word-by-word commentary
شرح قولي
Explains each phrase of the matn directly, sticking closely to the author’s wording.


Blended or integrated commentary
شرح مزجي / شرح مخلوط
The commentator mixes the matn with explanation, often adding their own legal opinions and preferences within the text.










Al-Waraqat is one of the shortest yet most foundational texts in usul al-fiqh. Regardless of one’s status in knowledge (beginner, intermediate and advanced), it serves as a primary reference that is incredibly beneficial. It is:

A matn, written by Imam al-Juwayni, independent of any other work. By this, I mean that when the great Imam wrote the work, he didn’t reference another book prior and is original work by Imam al-Juwayni.

Explained by Imam al-Mahalli in this sharh

Often accompanied by hashiyah in later editions by scholars.

Understanding these layers helps the student know:

What is original text (matn)
What is commentary (sharh)
What is later explanation (hashiyah)
Where the commentator adds his own reasoning or correction




Classical scholars state: “Whoever wishes to master a science must know its ten foundations (mabadiʿ).” These principles provide context about the subject, its purpose, and its benefit.

Hadd (الحد) – Definition of the science

The first principle (al-Hadd) is the definition. It’s imperative we ask outselves what exactly is Usul al-Fiqh, i.e, what is the Hadd for these words?
The remaining nine foundations of knowledge will be covered in subsequent lessons, insha’Allah as Sheikh Abdullahi has stated, although he’s hinted at what some of these are verbally from the first lecture. Some of the things I recall are Mauduʿ (subject matter) and Thamara (fruits/benefits in learning a science) to name a couple.




Understanding one’s level of study is essential, not only because it clarifies which books, teachers, and goals are appropriate, but also because it places a person’s knowledge into perspective and, often, instills a necessary humility about how limited a beginner student’s understanding truly is.

وَفَوْقَ كُلِّ ذِى عِلْمٍ عَلِيمٌۭ
[…But above those ranking in knowledge is the One All-Knowing.]
Surah Yusuf: Verse 76







Level
Description




Mubtadi’ (Beginner)
Cannot understand a legal issue (mas’ala) independently when reading a text or hearing it explained. Relies entirely on the teacher.


Mutawassit (Intermediate)
Can open a book, understand its masā’il, and follow the author’s reasoning with minimal help.


Muntahi (Advanced/Expert)
Can read advanced works, understand differing opinions, derive evidences from Qur’an and Sunnah, and explain rulings to others.








The phrase Usul al-Fiqh (أصول الفقه) is made up of two singular words (mufradat): Usul + Fiqh.

Together, they form a tarkib idafi (construct phrase) — like “House of Allah,” “Book of Salah,” etc.












Word
Arabic
Linguistic Meaning




Usul
أصول
Foundations, roots, or that upon which something is built.


Fiqh
فقه
Literally understanding something.









Example in Arabic Usage: هذا / ذلك




هذا (this) refers to something near or built upon something certain.

ذلك (that) refers to something distant or previously referred to.








Linguistically, fiqh means to understand something as it is.






Usage of Ma’rifah and Ilm



Sheikh Abdullahi brought up an interesting point (around the 1:03:00 mark in the lesson), one that caught my eye initially when seeing the text — Imam al-Haramain uses the term ma’rifah in his text, although Sheikh Abdullahi mentions that other commentators use ’ilm.
The two terms are interchangeable in most contexts, but as mentioned previously, one must exercise caution when distinguishing linguistic meanings from technical meanings within a science.













’Ilm (علم) vs Maʿrifah (معرفة)




Ma’rifah (Cognizance):

Perceiving something as it is.

’Ilm (Knowledge):

Knowing a thing and how it relates to another (this is often contextual to a science)


Example:
- Knowing salah is an act, and wajib means obligatory is ma’rifah.
- Knowing that salah is wajib and understanding the reason and evidence within the relevant context is ’ilm.






Use this checklist to review what you’ve learned and ensure you understand the lecture material from Lecture 1.



What is the definition (hadd) of Usul al-Fiqh?
How is the phrase “Usul al-Fiqh” grammatically structured?
What does “Usul” mean linguistically?
What does “Fiqh” mean linguistically?
What is the difference between ʿilm and maʿrifah? Can I explain it with an example?





What are the three levels of students in traditional learning?
Can I clearly differentiate their abilities?




Can I define each of the following in my own words:

Matn (متن) — What is its purpose?
Sharh (شرح) — What is its function?
Two Types of Sharḥ:
Hashiyah (حاشية) — When and why did it appear historically?

Taʿliqat (تعليقات) — How does it differ from a full commentary?

Taqrirat (تقريرات) — Where is it written, and why?


Make sure you can answer these before moving on to the next lesson. وبالله التوفيق.

title: Commentary of “Al-Waraqat” by Imam Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli
text:
The long-term goal of this project is to provide an accessible, organized study companion for English-speaking students of sacred law, based on Sharh al-Waraqat by Imam Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli, and taught according to reliable Shafi’i methodology and sources by Sheikh Abdullahi Shire (Miraath Institute) (Instagram).
This work was originally inspired by a fellow student (may Allah preserve him and protect him) who inquired about my note-taking approach a while back. In the spirit of classical tradition, I was reminded of Ta’lim al-Muta’allim fi Tariq al-Ta’allum (Instruction of the Student: The Method of Learning), which outlines adab and practical methods for serious seekers of sacred knowledge.
Read the English translation of Ta’lim al-Muta’allim



The content follows the topical arrangement of Sharh al-Waraqat by Imam al-Mahalli, beginning with biographies of the author (Imam al-Haramayn al-Juwayni) and the commentator (Imam Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli), then progressing through the essential chapters of Usul al-Fiqh, including, but not limited to categories of speech, rulings, commands and prohibitions, general and specific texts, abrogation, consensus, analogy (qiyas), and independent legal reasoning (ijtihad).




Many students struggle to retain English explanations while following the Arabic text, especially when encountering unfamiliar words and concepts related to the subject matter at hand. Research from the University of Pennsylvania shows that students remember up to 70% of material when they write concise notes and review them within 24 hours, compared to less than 30% if no active note-taking or review is done.








Before the Lesson




Print or bring the Arabic text of Sharh al-Waraqat. Lightly number each line or key statement in the matn.
Keep a separate notebook or tablet for your notes — leave space beside each line number to write explanations.
Draw a narrow left column for keywords or questions and a larger right section for class explanations and commentary.
Leave a bottom section or back of the page for summarizing what you learned after class.







Structure your notebook page/notetaking device like this:







Section
Purpose




Left Margin (small)
Write Arabic line number, key term, or question.


Main Notes Area (right side)
English explanation, teacher’s commentary, definitions, examples.


Bottom of Page / Separate Box
Summary of lesson, unresolved questions, or reflections.



You may lightly underline important words in the Arabic text, but full explanations should remain in the notebook or be referenced from reliable translations. In addition, always, when referencing or quoting a hadith by the Prophet Muhammad, always write out Salawat in it’s full form (صلى الله عليه وسلم).











Color
Use For




Blue
Key Arabic terms & definitions.


Green
Important commentary or explanations from Sheikh Abdullahi Shire.


Red
Questions, uncertainties, or topics to review or ask about.







Research shows that reviewing notes at spaced intervals drastically increases retention. A simple routine I’ve found to be helpful is:








Time
What to Do
Why?




Within 24-48 hours
Reread your notes and add missing details (this is especially important if you are re-watching the lectures and catch important missed information)
This prevents forgetting up to 50–80% of material.


After 3-6 days
Revisit and summarize the key ideas in your own words. If you’re able to, explain to other students in the class.
This not only reinforces your own understanding, but helps other students benefit as well and helps build lasting relationships with students you may take subsequent classes with.

title: Commentary of “Al-Waraqat” by Imam Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli
section: 2.1 Biography of Imam al-Haramain al-Juwayni (419–478 AH / 1028–1085 CE)
text:
2.1 Biography of Imam al-Haramain al-Juwayni (419–478 AH / 1028–1085 CE)

2.1.1 Birth and Background
He is Shaykh al-Islam, the jurist, theologian, and master of usul, the Shaykh of the Shafi‘is, the Imam of the Imams — Imam al-Haramain Abu al-Ma‘ali Abd al-Malik ibn Abd Allah ibn Yusuf al-Juwayni al-Naysaburi.
He was born into a well-known scholarly family among the people of knowledge, virtue, piety, and asceticism.
His father, Abu Muhammad Abd Allah al-Juwayni, was among the great imams of Islam. The son grew up under his care, acquiring knowledge from him, memorizing, studying, and refining his worship. He advanced in fiqh, usul, tafsir, and adab.

Grandfather: Yusuf ibn Abd Allah, a distinguished man of letters.

Paternal uncle: Abu al-Hasan Ali ibn Yusuf al-Juwayni, known as the Shaykh of the Hijaz.

His era was among the most brilliant centuries; scholars flourished in every discipline and the intellectual climate refined his scholarship.



2.1.2 His Teachers
He sought knowledge tirelessly with many leading scholars:

His father, Imam Abu Muhammad al-Juwayni.

Abu al-Qasim al-Iskafi al-Isfarayini, learned jurist in usul.

Abu al-Hasan Ali ibn Faddal al-Majjashi‘i, grammarian and literatus.
He also heard hadith from Abu Hasan, Abu Sa‘id ibn ’Alayyak, and Abu Sa‘id al-Nasrawi, among others.



2.1.3 His Students
He taught numerous eminent figures, including:

Abu Hamid al-Ghazali (Hujjat al-Islam), author of Ihya‘ ’Ulum al-Din.

Imad al-Din Abu al-Hasan Ali ibn Muhammad al-Harrasi, author of valuable works.

The jurist Ahmad ibn Muhammad al-Khawwafi al-Naysaburi (a contemporary).







Praise for His Students



Imam al-Juwayni said:
> “Al-Ghazali is a deep ocean, al-Kiya is a blazing lion, and al-Khawwafi is a consuming fire.”








Praise from Scholars




Al-Dhahabi: “The great Imam, Shaykh of the Shafi‘iyyah, Imam al-Haramain.”

Al-Subki: “Imam, Shaykh of Islam, sea of knowledge, precise scholar, theologian and usuli, eloquent and unmatched — famed East and West.”

Abu Uthman al-Sabuni: “He is the very eye of Islam today, defending it with eloquence.”





2.1.4 His Works

Nihayat al-Matlab fi Dirayat al-Madhhab

Al-Burhan fi Usul al-Fiqh

Al-Irshad ila Qawati‘ al-Adillah fi Usul al-I‘tiqad

Al-Waraqat fi Usul al-Fiqh

Luma‘ al-Adillah

Ghayat al-Umam fi Ithbat al-’Adl li al-Hakam
…and others.



2.1.5 His Death
He passed away in 478 AH (1085 CE). May Allah envelop him in His mercy, Allahumma ameen.

section: 2.2 Biography of Imam Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli (791–864 AH / 1389–1459 CE)
text:
2.2 Biography of Imam Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli (791–864 AH / 1389–1459 CE)

2.2.1 Birth and Background
He is the learned, precise imam — hadith scholar, jurist, theologian, exegete, and grammarian —
Jalal al-Din Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Muhammad al-Ansari al-Mahalli al-Qahiri al-Shafi‘i.
Born in Cairo in 791 AH (1389 CE), he dedicated himself to both transmitted and rational sciences and excelled in most of what he studied.


2.2.2 His Teachers
He studied under many great imams:

Siraj al-Din Abu Hafs ’Umar ibn ’Ali (Ibn al-Mulqin)

Shaykh al-Islam al-Bulqini (Abu Hafs ’Umar ibn Raslan al-Qahiri al-Shafi‘i)

Wali al-Din Abu Zur‘ah Ahmad ibn ’Abd al-Raheem al-’Iraqi

Shihab al-Din Ahmad ibn ’Ali al-Kinani (Ibn Hajar al-’Asqalani) — Commander of the Faithful in Hadith



2.2.3 His Students
Students who graduated from his teaching include:

Abu al-Fida’ Isma‘il ibn Ibrahim (Ibn Jama‘ah)

Abu ’Abd Allah Muhammad ibn ’Abd al-Rahman al-Dimashqi (Ibn Qadi ’Ajlun)

Shams al-Din Muhammad ibn ’Abd al-Rahman al-Sakhawi

Jalal al-Din al-Suyuti

Abu al-Hasan ’Ali ibn ’Abd Allah al-Sharif al-Samhudi — scholar of Madinah







Praise from Scholars




Al-Sakhawi: “Precise, sharp-minded, careful with his time, ascetic in spirit, and the Sheikh of the Shafi‘is at the Mu’ayyadiyya and Barquqiyya institutions; an imam, verifier, deeply insightful and intelligent.”

Al-Suyuti: “A sign of intelligence and understanding.”

Ibn al-Imad: “The Taftazani of the Arabs — the imam, the learned scholar.”





2.2.4 His Works

Al-Badr al-Tali‘ fi Hall Jam‘ al-Jawami‘ (Commentary on Subki’s Jam’ al-Jawami’ on Usul al Fiqh)

Sharh al-Waraqat (this commentary)

Kanz al-Raghibin fi Sharh Minhaj al-Talibin (Commentary on Imam Nawawi’s Minhaj in Fiqh)
…and others.



2.2.5 His Death
He passed away in 864 AH (1459 CE). May Allah have abundant mercy on him. Allahumma ameen.

title: 1 Lecture I: Course Introduction to al-Waraqat and the Science of Usul al-Fiqh [11/8/2025, Jumada al-Awwal 17, 1447 AH]
text:
Al-Qadi (القاضي)
Commonly used to refer to Qadi Abu Bakr al-Baqillani, though occasionally applied to other jurists who served as chief judges or early authorities in kalam and usul (like Qadi Abu Shuja’)
Al-Imam (الإمام)
Designates Imam al-Haramayn al-Juwayni, the teacher of al-Ghazali and a pivotal systematizer of Shafi’i usul.
Al-Shaykhayn (الشيخان)
Always refers to Imam al-Rafi’i and Imam al-Nawawi, whose opinions together form the later mu’tamad (established) position of the madhhab.
Asab al-Wujuh (أصحاب الوجوه)
A select group of early mujtahid Imams within the madhhab who formulated independent opinions (wujuh), later codified by scholars like al-Nawawi and al-Rafi’i.
Some of these include Imam Muzani, Hujjat al-Islam Abu Hamid al-Ghazali, Imam Buwayti, and Abu Ishaq al-Shirazi.
Al-Mujaddid (المجدد)
Refers to revivers of the school’s teaching and methodology in their respective centuries—e.g., al-Shafi’i in the 2nd century, al-Nawawi in the 7th century, al-Suyuti in the 10th.
Shaykh al-Islam (شيخ الاسلام)
Refers almost always to Shaykh al-Islam Zakariyyah al-Ansari, the Mujaddid of the 9th century, as well as the teacher of many luminaries including ibn Hajar al-Haytami, al-Khatib al-Shirbini, and Shams al-Din al-Ramli.
